inference:
The figure $ABCD$ is composed of two sectors of a circle with radius $12$ and central angles $60^\circ$.
The area of a sector with radius $r$ and central angle $\theta$ (in degrees) is given by the formula $\frac{\theta}{360^\circ} \times \pi r^2$.
The area of each sector is $\frac{60^\circ}{360^\circ} \times \pi (12^2) = \frac{1}{6} \times \pi (144) = 24\pi$.
The two sectors together have an area of $2 \times 24\pi = 48\pi$.
The two sectors together form a figure that looks like a circle segment, with the two sectors placed side by side.
Since the two sectors have a central angle of $60^{\circ}$ each, the two angles add up to $120^{\circ}$. The two sectors have a combined area of $2\times\frac{60}{360} \pi (12)^2 = 2\times\frac{1}{6} \pi(144) = 2\times24\pi = 48\pi$.
The combined area of the two sectors is $48\pi$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{48\pi}$
ground_truth: Each of sector $ABD$ and $BDC$ is one-sixth of a full circle of radius $12,$ so each has area one-sixth of the area of a circle of radius $12.$ Therefore, each sector has area $$\frac{1}{6}(\pi(12^2))=\frac{1}{6}(144\pi)=24\pi.$$ Thus, the area of figure $ABCD$ is $2( 24\pi)=\boxed{48\pi}.$
